Exponential growth


If \(a>1\) then it can be shown that, no matter how large \(K\) is: \[ \quad \dfrac{a^x}{x^K}\rightarrow\infty\quad \text{as}\quad x\rightarrow\infty\] That is, if \(K\) is fixed (though chosen as large as desired) then eventually, as \(x\) increases, \(a^x\) will become larger than the value \(x^K\) provided \(a>1\). The growth of \( a^x\) as \(x\) increases is called exponential growth. This limit tells us that exponential growth is eventually (large \(x\)) faster than polynomial growth of any degree.
